                  <name>
                     <namePart>J. Walter Thompson Company.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Wilson, Edward G.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Edward G. Wilson papers, 1906-1991 bulk 1946-1971.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection highlight's Wilson's 40-year career (1930-1971) as an executive with the J. Walter Thompson Company (JWT). The bulk of materials cover Wilson's return to JWT from military service in World War II until his retirement, and includes Wilson's writings and speeches, clippings, correspondence and memoranda. As General Counsel and head of JWT's legal department, Wilson oversaw contractual relations pertaining primarily to the sponsorship of radio and television programs for a number of clients--including DeBeers Consolidated Mines, Ltd., the Eastman Kodak Company, the Ford Motor Company, the Scott Paper Company and Unilever. The collection reveals JWT's relationships with radio and television personalities--such as Fred Allen and Edgar Bergen--and professional organizations like the Radio Writers Guild and the Television Writers of America. In addition, materials in the collection touch on the anti-communist movement and blacklisting within the U.S. entertainment industry of the 1950s--involving personalities such as Jean Muir and John Henry Faulk, among others. The collection also includes records from a number of JWT international offices, with heavier representation from offices in London; Bombay (Mumbai), India; and Johannesburg, South Africa, along with records kept by some of Wilson's predecessors, such as Donald Foote and Sam Meek, and the South African advertising executive and politician James Hamilton Russell. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Duke University Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <name>
                     <namePart>J. Walter Thompson Company. Frankfurt Office.</namePart>

                  <name>

                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Burkhard Schwarz Papers, 1969-1990 (bulk 1980-1989).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Schwarz was an advertising executive in the 1970s and 1980s. The collection includes correspondence, personnel files, financial summaries, client files, and files of prospects and new business contacts (ca. 1973-1989). Correspondence includes discussion of the company's reorganization in 1986 and attempts at collaboration with affiliated offices (e.g., Hill & Knowlton). Clients include Nestlé, Kodak, Burger King, Ford, Sunlicht, Elida, Kellogg, and DeBeers. Other material includes complete copies of lectures on business issues by JWT associates and others; JWT's 3 Year Plans (for the 1980s); and minutes and proceedings from European advertising symposia, both JWT specific (e.g. Managers Monthly Assessment, European Managers Meeting) and industry-wide (e.g. Davos, EPCOT). Most of the material is in German, but many files contain some English, especially correspondence with other JWT offices, symposia, and general JWT memoranda. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History. (96-009). </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Duke University Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke
			 University</corpname>
                  </repository>
                  <origination>
                     <corpname>J. Walter Thompson
			 Company.</corpname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>J. Walter Thompson Company.
		  Don Johnston Papers,
		  <unitdate>1964-1996 and
			 undated</unitdate>
                  </unittitle>
                  <langmaterial>Material
		  in <language> English</language>
                  </langmaterial>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>17.5 Linear Feet</extent>
                     <lb/>
                     <extent>12000
		  Items</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <physloc>For current information on the location of
		  these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.</physloc>
                  <abstract>The J. Walter Thompson
		  Company (JWT), founded in 1864, is one of the oldest and largest enduring
		  advertising agencies in the United States. Don Johnston held many positions at
		  JWT, beginning his career as a trainee in the Detroit mailroom and retiring as
		  CEO and President.</abstract>
                  <abstract>The Don Johnston Papers span the years
		  1964-1996 and document his career in various positions with JWT. The collection
		  includes international and domestic inter-office correspondence, personal and
		  administrative files, management manuals, presentations, speeches, budgets,
		  billings and profit reports, and video-cassettes that relate to planning for
		  JWT projects, committee meetings, marketing research, contracts with clients,
		  management directives, and JWT's corporate mission and philosophy. The papers
		  also touch on Joseph O'Donnell's attempted hostile takeover of the JWT Group,
		  and the purchase of JWT by the WPP Group. Clients represented include: Ford
		  Motor Company, Unilever, Chevron, General Foods, and Uniroyal Tire. Offices
		  represented include: Buenos Aires, Toronto, Chicago, Santiago, Detroit, Paris,
		  Frankfurt, Bombay (Mumbai), London, Tokyo, New York, and Johannesburg.
		  </abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: J. Walter Thompson Company.  Don Johnston Papers, 1964-1996 and undated
resource.abstract: The J. Walter Thompson  Company (JWT), founded in 1864, is one of the oldest and largest enduring  advertising agencies in the United States. Don Johnston held many positions at  JWT, beginning his career as a trainee in the Detroit mailroom and retiring as  CEO and President. The Don Johnston Papers span the years  1964-1996 and document his career in various positions with JWT. The collection  includes international and domestic inter-office correspondence, personal and  administrative files, management manuals, presentations, speeches, budgets,  billings and profit reports, and video-cassettes that relate to planning for  JWT projects, committee meetings, marketing research, contracts with clients,  management directives, and JWT's corporate mission and philosophy. The papers  also touch on Joseph O'Donnell's attempted hostile takeover of the JWT Group,  and the purchase of JWT by the WPP Group. Clients represented include: Ford  Motor Company, Unilever, Chevron, General Foods, and Uniroyal Tire. Offices  represented include: Buenos Aires, Toronto, Chicago, Santiago, Detroit, Paris,  Frankfurt, Bombay (Mumbai), London, Tokyo, New York, and Johannesburg.
resource.displayEntry: J. Walter Thompson Company. Don Johnston Papers, 1964-1996 and undated

                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Yale Peruvian Expedition papers, 1908-1948 (inclusive).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Correspondence, administrative records, scientific reports, writings, and illustrative material on the three expeditions to Peru sponsored by Yale University between 1911-1915. The most celebrated discoveries, the finding of Machu Picchu and of Vitcos, the last capital of the Incas, were studied during the expeditions by scientific specialists who were drawn principally from the Yale faculty. The papers include their diaries, manuscripts, and published reports of their work, as well as the writings of Hiram Bingham III, professor of Latin American history at Yale, and leader of the expeditions. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

The most celebrated discoveries, the finding of Machu Picchu and of Vitcos, the last capital of the Incas, were studied during the expeditions by scientific specialists who were drawn principally from the Yale faculty. The papers include their diaries, manuscripts, and published reports of their work, as well as the writings of Hiram Bingham III, professor of Latin American history at Yale, and leader of the expeditions.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:702149938</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:CtY-BR</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Stieglitz, Alfred, 1864-1946.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>O'Keeffe, Georgia, 1887-1986.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Alfred Stieglitz / Georgia O'Keeffe archive, 1728-1986 (bulk 1880-1986).</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The Alfred Stieglitz/Georgia O'Keeffe Archive contains correspondence files, manuscripts, documentary ephemera, photographs, art, and realia related to the lives and careers of Alfred Stieglitz and Georgia O'Keeffe, his second wife, and to other members of Stieglitz's family. The first subgroup, Alfred Stieglitz Papers, consists of material documenting Stieglitz's life's work: correspondence with artists, photographers, and writers; manuscripts by Stieglitz and others describing the art movements of the early twentieth century; scrapbooks; an autograph collection; prints of photographs by Stieglitz and other noted photographers; awards given to Stieglitz for his work; several works of art such as four poster portraits by Charles Demuth; and notebooks assembled posthumously to record the contents of Stieglitz's extensive art collection before it was dispersed following his death. The second subgroup, Georgia O'Keeffe Papers, consists primarily of correspondence from O'Keeffe's colleagues, friends, and family along with a number of fan letters, subject files, and business correspondence addressing rights and reproductions of O'Keeffe's works. This subgroup also includes files of documentary ephemera and a number of awards and medals given to O'Keeffe. The third subgroup, Stieglitz Family Papers, consists of correspondence, documentary ephemera, and drawings from Stieglitz family members, principally Alfred's parents, Edward and Hedwig. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Alfred Stieglitz / Georgia O'Keeffe archive, 1728-1986 (bulk 1880-1986).
resource.abstract: The Alfred Stieglitz/Georgia O'Keeffe Archive contains correspondence files, manuscripts, documentary ephemera, photographs, art, and realia related to the lives and careers of Alfred Stieglitz and Georgia O'Keeffe, his second wife, and to other members of Stieglitz's family. The first subgroup, Alfred Stieglitz Papers, consists of material documenting Stieglitz's life's work: correspondence with artists, photographers, and writers; manuscripts by Stieglitz and others describing the art movements of the early twentieth century; scrapbooks; an autograph collection; prints of photographs by Stieglitz and other noted photographers; awards given to Stieglitz for his work; several works of art such as four poster portraits by Charles Demuth; and notebooks assembled posthumously to record the contents of Stieglitz's extensive art collection before it was dispersed following his death. The second subgroup, Georgia O'Keeffe Papers, consists primarily of correspondence from O'Keeffe's colleagues, friends, and family along with a number of fan letters, subject files, and business correspondence addressing rights and reproductions of O'Keeffe's works. This subgroup also includes files of documentary ephemera and a number of awards and medals given to O'Keeffe. The third subgroup, Stieglitz Family Papers, consists of correspondence, documentary ephemera, and drawings from Stieglitz family members, principally Alfred's parents, Edward and Hedwig.
resource.extent: 168 linear ft. (260 boxes) + 2 broadside folders + 10 art objects.
resource.displayEntry: Stieglitz, Alfred, 1864-1946. Alfred Stieglitz / Georgia O'Keeffe archive, 1728-1986 (bulk 1880-1986).

                  <abstract>The Media Resources and Research Department was responsible for media research and media planning support activities within JWT's Chicago Office. Collection primarily includes proprietary research reports on a wide variety of topics relevant to media planning, usage and evaluation. In addition, there are clippings, departmental administrative files, a U-matic videocassette; and writings and speeches of key departmental executives. Topics include general media planning and effectiveness research; studies on newspapers, magazines and other print media; broadcast and cable television viewing and television commercials; outdoor advertising research; radio advertising; video and VCR usage research; demographic research, especially on media usage among women, young people, and African Americans; and international media studies. Client-specific research includes case studies of Kodak; Kraft; the U.S. Marine Corps; and Warner-Lambert. There is also a small reference library of materials published by other research firms including A.C. Nielsen; Audit Bureau of Circulations; Daniel Starch; and Magazine Publishers Association. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Duke University Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Granger Tripp papers, 1958-1984.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Collection chiefly consists of presentations and speeches, but also includes correspondence, memoranda, publications, and clippings, as well as a manuscript score for the Kodak song "The Times of Your Life," photographs, and audiovisual material. The collection mainly reflects Granger Tripp's role as creative supervisor directing the creative work at the J. Walter Thompson Company between 1966 and 1984. It document's the contents and strategies of creative advertisement for the Eastman Kodak Company, as well as advertisement strategy and philosophy of the J. Walter Thompson Company in general. In addition to writings by Granger Tripp, the collection contains various writings, correspondence and memoranda of other members of the J. Walter Thompson Company creative team, including Jeremy Bullmore, Burt Manning, Douglass C. Harvey, Sonja Suspeh, Don Johnston and Joel Baumwoll. Covering material that is client-specific as well as general in nature, the Granger Tripp collection consists of one large series referring explicitly to the collaboration between JWT and the Eastman Kodak Company and three additional series referring to the creative work of JWT in general. The Eastman Kodak Series documents the development, execution and public reaction to various creative advertising campaigns developed by the J. Walter Thompson Company for the Eastman Kodak Company. A Speeches And Writings Series refers to the company's strategies and philosophy in general. A small Publication Series contains publications on commercials for Eastman Kodak as well as advertising in general. An Audiovisual Series documents Granger Tripp's late affiliation with the Ford Motor Company. It consists of one u-matic video tape on the development of the Ford Taurus, 1986. Acquired as part of the John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Duke University Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Donald M. McMaster papers, 1963-1975.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Tape and transcript of an interview, 1967; transcript of an interview, 1968; video recording about photography; and nine photographs relating to the video recording. Interviews cover McMaster's association with Cornell as a student and as a trustee, and with the Eastman Kodak Company from the time he joined it in 1917 until he retired. Also twelve mounted color photographs of various scenes including Nassau, Rio de Janeiro, London, and a rural scene taken by McMaster. Also, correspondence (1963-1975) with Dale Corson and others; and a tape recording of Edward J. Trethaway's recollection of McMaster. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Cornell University Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>

               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.title: The Mohawk Valley
resource.abstract: Shows cities and landmarks in the Mohawk Valley. Views of Schenectady a N.Y., include mules pulling a barge up the Erie Canal, the General Electric plant, and the Great Western Gateway Bridge. Shows activities in a carpet factory in Amsterdam and the operation of the locks at Little Falls. Cloth is cut and sewn at a textile factory in Utica. Copper is rolled and fabricated at a Rome factory.
resource.displayEntry: The Mohawk Valley
